## Info

### Whatâ€™s the challenge?

In this thrilling challenge, you will dive into the world of statistics from the [4TU.ResearchData repository](https://data.4tu.nl/). Once you register, we'll provide instructions on how to access the data and submit your work.

### How to participate?

The tool of choice for this challenge is R! You must upload your visualizations along with the R code that brought them to life, accompanied by a brief description of your project. The rest is limited only by your imagination!

### Whenâ€™s the deadline?

:::{.callout-note}
## Submission deadline

**9th October 2023, 12PM**

:::


You'll have two weeks to submit your visualizations before the showcase event on October 11th from 3:00 PM to 6:30 PM. During this event, you'll present your work, and we'll feature an engaging keynote speech while announcing the challenge winners!



### Where do you work?

You can craft your visualizations at your own pace and in your own space. However, the showcase event, where you present your work will be hosted in the inviting Orange Room at the TU Delft Library.

### Need Help?

Should you encounter any challenges during the competition, there are numerous ways to ask for help.

#### Join self-help MS Teams channel 
If you're stuck with a data visualization channel, post your question in the Plot-a-thon self-help Channel, for other participants and organizers to answer. Like that we learn together!

#### Drop by online info session
If you would like to meet us and ask questions live, join the Q&A drop-in session online. The session will take place on Wednesday, 27th September, 12:45 - 13:45. 
 
#### Send us an email
If you have questions about the challenge or organization, you can always reach out to us at [rcafe-lib@tudelft.nl](mailto: rcafe-lib@tudelft.nl) for support!

### Grading Criteria 

Here are the main criteria we will use to grade the data visualizations.
 
| criterion/score | 0 | 1 | 2 | 3 |
|----|----|----|----|----|
| information | The information on the visualisation is not accurate. It is unclear what the visualisation is supposed to depict. | The information in the visualisation is mostly accurate and can be fully understood with the aid of a presentation. | The information on the visualisation is accurate and easily understood without additional information from the creator. Labels, legends, and axes are clearly labeled. |
| visual appeal | That's nice... | Not bad! | Ooooh pretty! | ðŸ¤©ðŸ¤©ðŸ¤© |
| analysis | Limited data wrangling. No comments provided in code. | Good use of data wrangling to access additional trends in the data. Limited comments provided. | Great use of data wrangling to access information within the dataset. Great use of comments to guide the reader through the code | |
| reproducibility | Visualisation required more than three interventions to reproduce. | Visualisation reproducible with two or three interventions. | Visualisation reproducible with only a single intervention. | Fully reproducible with no intervention. Works on Linux (Ubuntu), MacOS, and Windows. |
